Roger Goodell problem

KANSAS Town, Mo. ?a NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell expressed frustration Thursday within the lack of negotiations toward a brand new collective bargaining agreement.

Throughout a call with Kansas City Chiefs followers, Goodell reiterated the league's want to resume negotiations using the locked-out players. The venue is a vital distinction and also the commissioner and owners have repeatedly accused the gamers of walking absent from negotiations in March, kicking off the federal court battle that has incorporated four days of judge-ordered mediation.

"Unfortunately, I don't think we're making much progress in negotiations simply because they really are not happening," Goodell said around the contact. "Right now, it is inside a litigation phase and the union is pursuing that while we are defending that. Sadly, you will find not sufficient negotiations, which eventually it's going to have to arrive back again to and it is where this will get resolved and end in a new collective bargaining agreement."

The next date for court-ordered talks before a federal magistrate is Might sixteen.
Chiefs proprietor Clark Hunt told callers that small-market groups like the Chiefs could be at a aggressive drawback with big-market groups if the NFL doesn't adjust to the times.

For an instance, Hunt needs only to watch the small-market Kansas Town Royals. Unable to match the richer clubs' salary provides for leading players the Royals have created, Kansas City has been shut out of baseball's postseason because 1985.

"It's incredibly important to get a team such as the Kansas Town Chiefs that we've a collective bargaining agreement that's good for all 32 clubs," Hunt stated. "We do not desire a program that heads within the path of baseball. We have some concern that this has the potential to go that way. We want a deal that allows our fantastic game to carry on to grow."

The 30-minute teleconference created no fireworks, bombshells or breaking news around the labor dispute that has brought the NFL to a standstill. Goodell has conducted similar question-and-answer sessions with other clubs because the lockout began.

Nonetheless, a number of fans, recognized only by initial name, were able to make some points. Joan, a season ticket holder since 1963, was concerned about players' conditioning during the lockout.
